review.title: Automatic Breast Ultrasound Image Segmentation: A Survey
review.abstract: Breast cancer is one of the leading causes of cancer death among women worldwide. In clinical routine, automatic breast ultrasound (BUS) image segmentation is very challenging and essential for cancer diagnosis and treatment planning. Many BUS segmentation approaches have been studied in the last two decades, and have been proved to be effective on private datasets. Currently, the advancement of BUS image segmentation seems to meet its bottleneck. The improvement of the performance is increasingly challenging, and only few new approaches were published in the last several years. It is the time to look at the field by reviewing previous approaches comprehensively and to investigate the future directions. In this paper, we study the basic ideas, theories, pros and cons of the approaches, group them into categories, and extensively review each category in depth by discussing the principles, application issues, and advantages/disadvantages.

metadata.title: Automatic Breast Ultrasound Image Segmentation: A Survey

sections.text: 1 / 71 Breast cancer is one of the world's leading causes of cancer death in women. In routine clinical practice, automated breast image segmentation by ultrasound (BUS) is proving to be very difficult and indispensable for cancer diagnosis and treatment planning. Many BUS segmentation approaches have been researched over the past two decades and have proven effective on private datasets. Currently, the evolution of BUS image segmentation appears to be resolving its bottleneck. Improving performance is becoming increasingly difficult, and few new approaches have been published in recent years. It is time to look at the field through a comprehensive review of previous approaches and examine the future directions. In this paper, we examine the basic ideas, theories, pros and cons of the approaches, group them into categories, and examine each category in depth by discussing the principles, application questions, and pros and cons.

sections.heading: 2.4 Summary
sections.text: Graph-based approaches make up the second largest share of BUS image segmentation literature (Fig. 1), but they are among the earliest techniques for BUS image segmentation, fading due to the successful application of other powerful approaches such as deformable models (Section 3), 14 / 71, and rising again because of the dramatic advances of graph models and energy optimization algorithms. MRF-MAP-ICM is a flexible framework for image multiple partition (not just tumor or or non-tumor). Most BUS image segmentation approaches based on this framework achieve good performance by developing better probability energy and obtaining better initialization. Only obtaining a locally optimal solution is the main deficit of these approaches. Graph sections provide an efficient framework for image bipartitioning and MRF energy global optimization and are the most important factor for making graph-based models popular again in US image segmentation.

sections.heading: 3. Deformable models
sections.text: Deformable models (DMs) are curves or surfaces that can move towards the boundary of the object under the influence of forces defined on the curve or surface, using the knowledge of the image. DMs can handle biological structures with significant variability and allow the user to integrate expertise to guide segmentation when needed; hence they have been extensively applied to BUS image segmentation over the last ten years. DMs are proposed by Terzopoulos [37] and then become a popular and active field according to the serpent approach to the flat image proposed by Kass et al. [38]. In general, DMs can be divided into two categories according to the curve or surface representation during deformation: (1) the parametric DMs (PDMs) and (2) the geometric DMs (GDMs). In PDMs, curves or surfaces can be explicitly represented by their topical form (), as topical (), (e.g.), () topical (), ().

sections.heading: 3.1 Parametric deformable models
sections.text: Finding object boundaries (parameterized curves and surfaces) with the help of PDMs is formulated to minimize an energy function, including internal and external energies; the internal term is used to control the continuity and smoothness of curves and surfaces; and the external energy function is calculated using image characteristics to tighten curves to the object boundary (). 17 / 71Let () = (), (), (), (), [0, 1] will be a deformable curve; it moves to the optimal object boundary by minimizing () + () + (15) The internal energy is derived by () = 1 2 (), (), (), (16), the first order being derived from C, which holds the continuity of the curve, and the second order, which controls the smoothness of the curve; and the large one will cause the change in the distances between points on the curve to cause high costs.

sections.heading: 3.2 Geometric deformable models (GDMs)
sections.text: GDMs [40, 41] are proposed to overcome the two primary limitations of PDMs: misrepresentation of adaptability and parameter dependence. In GDMs, a 2D curve (C) in time t is implicitly represented as the zero level of a scalar function () and (,) the unit normal vector of an evolutionary curve in time t is used; the partial derivative of C in relation to the unit standard and curvature and the image properties. (,) The velocity and unit normal vector of an evolutionary curve in time is used.

sections.heading: 3.3 Edge-based vs. Region-based DMs
sections.text: DMs provide a flexible framework for image segmentation that can incorporate both low-threshold image characteristics and various prior knowledge, such as edge, local regional statistics, shape and intensity distribution. Depending on the information on the construction of external force in PDMs or velocity function in GDMs, DMs can be divided into edge-based [38, 41, 42, 44, 48] and region-based [47, 49, 66]. Edge-based DMs aim to draw the developing curve to the object boundary by defining the deformation force or speed using the image gradient [42-44], and the models depend on the image flow to stop the curve deformation. Region-based DMs model region characteristics to control curve deformation; by modeling local regional characteristics, region-based models can usually perform better than edge-based models, especially when images have high noise and weak object boundaries.

sections.heading: 4. Learning-based approaches
sections.text: Image segmentation can also be considered a classification problem by dividing pixels or superpixels into different categories. Therefore, it is quite common to apply machine learning approaches to image segmentation tasks, using both supervised and unsupervised learning approaches. By applying the unsupervised methods, the BUS image is first split into fragmented regions and then used prior knowledge (location, size, appearance, etc.) to determine the final tumor region.

sections.heading: 4.3 Summary
sections.text: Unattended learning is simple and fast and has been widely used in many BUS image segmentation approaches. However, due to the difficult nature of BUS image segmentation, unattended approaches are only used as a pre-processing step to generate image regions for candidates, and more complex methods are typically used for final segmentation; for example, in [7, 9, 10] K means are used to estimate initial parameters of intensity or texture distribution; and in [89, 91] logistic regression is used to find cluster results to find the final tumor. Supervised Learning provides a good framework for integrating different feature levels and acquiring knowledge between input and target products. Many BUS image segmentation approaches perform well by using monitored learning approaches. Most of them design features using feature knowledge to improve performance.

sections.heading: 5. Classical Approaches: thresholding, region growing and watershed
sections.text: In this section, we will discuss some classic segmentation approaches to BUS image segmentation, which are usually combined with other methods to achieve good performance.

sections.heading: 5.1 Thresholding
sections.text: isholding is the most intuitive, simple, and fastest segmentation approach and enjoys popularity in BUS image segmentation. It groups image pixels directly into regions by using a single threshold (two classes) or multiple thresholds (multiple classes) based on pixel characteristics (e.g. intensity, color, local mean, standard deviation, etc.) A threshold th segments image pixels into two classes: () =, () >, () ≤ (35), where I (p) is the intensity of the pixel; and is the caption for two classes. If th is a constant over the entire image, the method is referred to as global threshold; if th changes over local characteristics, the method is referred to as adaptive / local threshold. Global threshold is fast and37 / 71 works well if the intensity distributions of objects and background are sufficiently clear; if the technical background contrast is low, the image is noise-free and there is no threshold (or no threshold).

sections.heading: 7. Fundamental Issues of BUS Image Segmentation
sections.text: In this section we discuss the basic problems of BUS segmentation and summarize the successful strategies used in modern approaches. 7.1 Denoising and Preserving Edge46 / 71 In ultrasound imaging, spot noise is inherent in coherent illumination and Rayleigh scattering caused by tissue edge structures [147], and there is a major difficulty in BUS image segmentation. Many de-speckle approaches have been used, such as center filters, Gaussian low-pass filters, spectral-reducing anisotropic diffusion (SRAD), non-linear coherence filters (NCD) [149], stick filters [60], bilateral filters [150, 151], fractional subpixel diffusion [157], etc.Mean filters and G61 filters (NCD), 115-low and fast-1359 filters.

sections.heading: 7.4 Validation: ground truth, metrics, and BUS image datasets
sections.text: Most of the BUS image segmentation approaches discussed in this paper have been evaluated quantitatively, and two important approaches have been used: the first approach is to evaluate segmentation performance by using physical phantoms or simulation software, e.g. Field II [155, 156]; the second approach to validation is that the segmentation result is very accurate; but the physical phantoms cannot accurately represent the real breast anatomy, and the simulation software uses a simple capture model and cannot well represent the real BUS imaging process; the second approach to validation is to compare the segmentation result with the manually delimited boundary; the problem with this approach is that the manually delimited basic truth may be flawed due to human error; however, this problem could be solved by multiple labeling of the boundary by the same person and / or multiple radiologists.

sections.heading: 8. Conclusions and Future Directions
sections.text: In this paper, we used the automatic BUS image segmentation approaches. First, we classified all approaches into four main categories based on basic technical principles. Second, in sections 2-5, we presented the theoretical principles of each method, discussed its advantages and disadvantages, and summarized the strategies for BUS image segmentation. Third, in section 6, approaches for other three small subcategories are briefly discussed. Fourth, in section 7, we discussed four basic open problems in BUS image segmentation and summarized future research directions.Unrestricted BUS image segmentation techniques: Currently, most BUS image segmentation techniques work well on BUS images collected in controlled settings, such as high image contrast artifacts that contain only one tumor per image, etc. However, their performance deteriorates greatly with BUS images that exhibit large variations in image quality, location and number of artifacts per image.

referenceMentions.context: Introduction Breast cancer occurs in the highest frequency in women among all cancers, and is also one of the leading causes of cancer death worldwide [1, 2].
Introduction Breast cancer occurs in the highest frequency in women among all cancers, and is also one of the leading causes of cancer death worldwide [1, 2].
The key of reducing the mortality is to find signs and symptoms of breast cancer at its early stage by clinic examination [3].

Breast ultrasound (BUS) imaging has become one of the most important and effective modality for the early detection of breast cancer because of its noninvasive, nonradioactive and cost-effective nature [4]; and it is most suitable for large scale breast cancer screening and diagnosis in low-resource countries and regions.

Graph-based approaches Graph-based approaches gain increasing popularity in BUS image segmentation because they offer several advantages: (1) they provide a simple way to organize task-related priors and image information in a unified framework; (2) they are flexible and suitable for expressing soft constraints between random variables; and (3) the computation based on graphical manipulation is very efficient [5].

metadata.abstractText: Breast cancer is one of the leading causes of cancer death among women worldwide. In clinical routine, automatic breast ultrasound (BUS) image segmentation is very challenging and essential for cancer diagnosis and treatment planning. Many BUS segmentation approaches have been studied in the last two decades, and have been proved to be effective on private datasets. Currently, the advancement of BUS image segmentation seems to meet its bottleneck. The improvement of the performance is increasingly challenging, and only few new approaches were published in the last several years. It is the time to look at the field by reviewing previous approaches comprehensively and to investigate the future directions. In this paper, we study the basic ideas, theories,pros and cons of the approaches, group them into categories, and extensively review each category in depth by discussing the principles, application issues, and advantages/disadvantages. Keyword: breast ultrasound (BUS) images, breast cancer, segmentation, benchmark, early detection, computer-aided diagnosis (CAD)
